node.title: Detecting Signs of Trouble in Schools
node.description: Discussing steps to reduce the number of school shootings. Also: Book censorship; hunger in Afghanistan; abortion after incest; what kind of America?

node.title: Internet Backs Man Who Makes Pregnant Wife Sleep in Guest Bedroom
node.description: The man said he asked his pregnant wife, who suffers from extreme sickness and insomnia, to sleep in the spare room.

node.title: Taliban Official Hopes U.S. Will Change Afghanistan Policies, Sanctions Have 'No Benefit'
node.description: The Afghan foreign minister said the U.S. and other countries should unfreeze $10 billion in funds and that weakening the government is not in their interest.

node.title: 1 Dead, 1 Missing as Authorities Call Off Search After Cargo Ships Collide
node.description: The Danish vessel Karin Hoej capsized and was floating upside down after a collision with the British ship Scot Carrier in the Baltic Sea.

node.title: Mayfield, Kentucky, Likely to Be Without Heat, Water for 'Long Time' After Deadly Tornado
node.description: The city of Mayfield has been left in shambles after a tornado Friday night. Mayfield reported having no running water, natural gas or wastewater management.

node.title: Woman Finds Alleged Bug Infestation Inside SHEIN Package in Viral Video
node.description: "Straight out of the package infested," the caption of the viral video read.

node.title: Zoo Successfully Breeds 6 Endangered Komodo Dragons for the First Time in Its History
node.description: Officials with the Bronx Zoo say there may be less than 2,500 of these dragons living in the wild.

node.title: How to Help Victims of the Deadly U.S. Tornadoes
node.description: Up to 100 people are feared dead after dozens of tornadoes ripped through six states. Here are some ways you can help those in need.

node.title: 57 Percent of Americans Still Wear Masks Around Others When Leaving Home: Poll
node.description: The Associated Press and NORC Center for Public Affairs Research poll was conducted with over 1,000 people in early December.

node.title: Florida COVID Cases Are Rising Faster Than Any Other State
node.description: Florida has been the subject of some of the United States' most devastating COVID-19 waves over the course of the pandemic.

node.title: Linda Hoffman, Harriet Carter, Separated at Birth, Meet for First Time After 73 Years
node.description: "I think we found each other when we were supposed to," said Linda Hoffman, 73, of her 76-year-old sister, Harriet Carter.

node.title: Apple on cusp of becoming first U.S. company worth $3 trillion
node.description: iPhone maker's market capitalization now tops the GDP of countries including Russia, India and France.

node.title: Live Updates: Tornado outbreak death toll in Kentucky rises to 64
node.description: Kentucky Governor Andy Beshear said his state suffered "the worst tornado event" in its history.

node.title: Duck for the Holidays
node.description: Melissa Clark’s latest is perfect for an elegant, small-scale celebration.

node.title: After 15 Years of Infighting, James Brown’s Estate Is Sold
node.description: The sale to Primary Wave Music, for an estimated $90 million, provides resources to ultimately realize the musician’s wish to fund scholarships for needy children.

node.title: South Carolina Man Dies After Falling Off Roof While Putting Up Christmas Lights
node.description: According to the U.S. Consumer Product Safety Commission, around 160 decorating-related injuries occur each day during the holiday season.

node.title: CDC Predicts U.S. COVID Deaths Will Rise As Britain Reports First Omicron Death
node.description: Deaths in the U.S. ticked down after the summer surge, but the CDC estimates an additional 40,000 people could die within the next four weeks.

node.title: Flattened Homes, Downed Trees: Videos Show Tornado Damage in Kentucky
node.description: "It's very likely going to be over 100 people lost here in Kentucky," Kentucky Governor Andy Beshear said.

node.title: What to Expect at Oxford Shooting Suspect Ethan Crumbley's Court Hearing Today
node.description: Crumbley will appear before a judge at 1:15 p.m. in Michigan. He faces 24 charges, including four counts of first-degree murder.

node.title: 5-Month-Old Among 64 Dead in Kentucky After Tornadoes Rip Through State
node.description: Six of the victims were under the age of 18, according to Governor Andy Beshear.

node.title: U.S. Diplomat Urges China to Take on Larger Climate Stance by Halting Use of Coal
node.description: China is currently the world's biggest consumer of coal power, generating 27% of carbon dioxide emissions.

node.title: People Finding Photos, Other Items from Homes Miles Away After Tornadoes Hit 5 States
node.description: In a Facebook group created to help reunite lost possessions with their owners, people have been posting pictures of family photos, checks and even pets.

node.title: Nicole Kidman lands Golden Globe nomination
node.description: Aussie actors Nicole Kidman and Sarah Snook have picked up Golden Globe nominations, with Netflix movies scoring a leading 17 nods.

node.title: Teenager detonates bomb at Moscow school, injuring 12
node.description: A graduate of an Orthodox School near Moscow detonates a homemade bomb inside the school injuring at least 12 people.

node.title: Golden Globes nominations announced
node.description: "Belfast" and "The Power of the Dog" tied for the most nominations with seven apiece.

node.title: The HPV Vaccine Prevents Cancer, but Most Kids Don’t Receive It
node.description: The human papillomavirus vaccine can prevent six potentially lethal malignancies, but inoculation is meeting with rising resistance from parents.

node.title: Merck’s Covid Pill Might Pose Risks for Pregnant Women
node.description: Some laboratory studies suggest that molnupiravir can insert errors in DNA, which could in theory harm a developing fetus, sperm cells or children.

node.title: COVID Lab Leak Probe After Scientist Bitten by Infected Animal
node.description: A lab worker tested positive for COVID-19 after being bitten twice by mice that were infected with the virus. It is unclear if the mouse bites are responsible for the infection.

node.title: Bill de Blasio Avoids Saying Whether NYC Companies Should Fire Unvaccinated Staff
node.description: De Blasio has mandated that all unvaccinated private sector workers in New York City get vaccinated by December 27 this year.

node.title: First Omicron death confirmed in U.K. as PM warns of "tidal wave" of infection
node.description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson says the variant will account for a majority of new COVID cases in London within a day as it spreads at a "phenomenal rate."
